statement:
**Theorem.** If $\alpha$ is an algebraic number, then there exists a
non-zero of $\alpha$ which is an algebraic integer.

[*Proof.*]{} Let $\alpha$ be a of the equation
$$x^n\!+\!r_1x^{n-1}\!+\!r_2x^{n-2}\!+\cdots+\!r_n = 0,$$ where $r_1$,
$r_2$, …, $r_n$ are rational numbers ($n > 0$). Let $l$ be the least
common multiple of the denominators of the $r_j$’s. Then we have
$$0 = l^n(\alpha^n\!+\!r_1\alpha^{n-1}\!+\!r_2\alpha^{n-2}\!+\cdots+\!r_n) =
 (l\alpha)^n\!+\!lr_1(l\alpha)^{n-1}\!+\!l^2r_2(l\alpha)^{n-2}\!+\cdots+\!l^nr_n,$$
i.e. the the algebraic equation
$$x^n\!+\!lr_1x^{n-1}\!+\!l^2r_2x^{n-2}\!+\cdots+\!l^nr_n = 0$$ with
rational integer coefficients.\
According to the theorem, any algebraic number $\xi$ is a of an
algebraic integer (of the field $\mathbb{Q}(\xi)$) and a rational
integer.
